node.bodyText:
hello
you could have done
  _Tester2[_qp].resize(LL, 0);

can you compile in debug mode and get a backtrace to make sure which line is seg-faulting?

-> 45  	    Tester2[_qp][i] = 35;
   46  	  }

ok I dont see why it s not doing what we want.
maybe initQpStateful is not actually overriding ?? Do you have override in the header for that declaration
add thiis in computeQpProperties
_Tester2[_qp].resize(LL);
it won't cause errors. You are resizing then filling the vector immediately.
Thank you so much

I just added a new vector to my existing code, which had been working well previously. These codes include several vectors and have been functioning without issues. After compiling the modified code, I encountered a Segmentation fault (core dumped) error.
Notably, before adding the new vector, I made some other modifications and tested the code. Everything worked perfectly, and all vectors operated as expected. However, as soon as I added the new vector, the segmentation fault error appeared. Even after removing the new vector and testing again, the error persisted.
This leads me to believe that the issue might be related to recent updates or changes in the main source code of the MOOSE framework
I should mention that using resize() in the computeQpProperties function is not a viable option for me, because it causes issues with vectorpostprocessors and postprocessors in my application (I get the segmentation fault error if I add a postprocessor for vectors)
Thank you for your assistance.

Hello
If you want to investigate this you will have to use a git bisect on recent changes to find which change may have caused the issue.
It's however quite unlikely as we run thousands of tests and recent changes in moose do not break those.
The seg fault with the postprocessors could be a clue. Which postprocessor are you using? What is it measuring?

Hi
I think the problem stems from the following code issue; please advise how I may resolve it.
#include errors detected. Please update your includePath. Squiggles are disabled for this translation unit (/home/sajjad/projects/precippanter/src/Materials/Inputs.C).C/C++(1696)
cannot open source file "Material.h" (dependency of "Inputs.h")C/C++(1696)

Material is a source file from the Moose framework and serves as the application's base class.
All relevant MOOSE framework source codes encountered the same issue.

In the following, you can see the VSCode setup

Sincerely,
Sajjad
this is a VSCode setup change? it wont cause a segfault

"Yes, however, I encountered an error (warning) in the source code, like Material.h."
Do you have any suggestion to fix it?

You can just ignore it, it's just VScode that is not properly set up
You can fix your VSCode setup by adding the path to search for header files

Do you have any insights regarding the segmentation fault? Could there be an issue with the Moose framework on my PC? I've updated Moose and my application twice in the last five days, but the error persists. I'm considering uninstalling and reinstalling Moose.

It's very unlikely to be due to moose. And much more likely to be due to a fault in the code in your application.
Follow the debugging instructions to get us a backtrace. Seg faults are good eerrors to have, they are easy to find

node.title: Input spatial data of "alpha" into Van Genuchten capillary model
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
In PorousFlow module, the Van Genuchten capillarity model is defined with two coefficients "alpha" and "m".

I understand that in the scripts "PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG.h" and "PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG.C" under UserObject, the alpha is set to be a single value as input.
If I want to include a file which contains the spatial data of alpha, like the heterogeneous permeability. Is there any simple way to include it?

Hello
You can modify the source code to use alpha as a function or as an auxiliary variable.
This should not be too difficult if you have followed the tutorial and created your own object once
Guillaume

[AuxVariables]
  [entry_p]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_from_file_var = alpha
  []
[]

this does not create an alpha variable you can use in PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha
unless you set the parameter alpha = entry_p

It shows error message "zsh: segmentation fault". Should I use another inputparameter type for the alpha array?

I would be worried about _alpha being used outside of an element loop. For example in the base classes of PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha.
You would need to check if that happens and prevent it.
For example you commented out this line in the constructor, which would have caused a segfault:
// _pc_sscale(PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(_s_scale, _alpha[0], _m, _pc_max))

To find instances of a call outside of the expected execution, you can use these instructions and look at the backtrace
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

Thank you for your quick reply!

[AuxVariables]
  [entry_p]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    initial_from_file_var = alpha
  []
[]

this does not create an alpha variable you can use in PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha unless you set the parameter alpha = entry_p

Yep, I assigned the "entry_p" to the "alpha"
[UserObjects]
  [pc] # Capillary pressure
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha
    alpha = entry_p # [Pa^-1]
    m = 0.6
  []
[]



It shows error message "zsh: segmentation fault". Should I use another inputparameter type for the alpha array?

I would be worried about _alpha being used outside of an element loop. For example in the base classes of PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha. You would need to check if that happens and prevent it. For example you commented out this line in the constructor, which would have caused a segfault:
// _pc_sscale(PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(_s_scale, _alpha[0], _m, _pc_max))


I think you are right, that the alpha may be used outside of an element loop. I am wondering is there anyway to take the alpha like the saturation variable, maybe the issue could be fixed. Currently I am using the qp to locate alpha in each mesh element.
The commented line was used directly in the capillary curve function, which replaced the original _pc_sscale:
Real
PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha::capillaryPressureCurve(Real saturation, unsigned qp) const
{
  const Real seff = effectiveSaturationFromSaturation(saturation) * _s_scale;
  return PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(seff, _alpha[qp], _m, _pc_max) -
         PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(_s_scale, _alpha[qp], _m, _pc_max);
}


To find instances of a call outside of the expected execution, you can use these instructions and look at the backtrace https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

I will do a try about this debugger.
Thanks again for your answer!
Check out https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/porous_flow/src/userobjects/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureBC.C for an example where the entry pressure pe can be a variable or a Real.
Sorry - scratch that! I mustn't have pushed that change but have it locally somewhere. I'll try and find it 😄

Sorry - scratch that! I mustn't have pushed that change but have it locally somewhere. I'll try and find it 😄

Looking forward to the commit. Thanks again for the discussion, very helpful!

So, what I had done is basically what you have here. I copied your code, compiled and ran a test and it seems to work ok.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 100
[]

[GlobalParams]
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
[]

[Variables]
  [p0]
    initial_condition = 1e6
  []
  [s1]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [s0aux]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
  [s1aux]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
  [p0aux]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
  [p1aux]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
  [alpha]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [s0]
    type = PorousFlowPropertyAux
    property = saturation
    phase = 0
    variable = s0aux
  []
  [s1]
    type = PorousFlowPropertyAux
    property = saturation
    phase = 1
    variable = s1aux
  []
  [p0]
    type = PorousFlowPropertyAux
    property = pressure
    phase = 0
    variable = p0aux
  []
  [p1]
    type = PorousFlowPropertyAux
    property = pressure
    phase = 1
    variable = p1aux
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [alpha]
    type = RandomIC
    variable = alpha
    min = 1e-5
    max = 1e-4
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [p0]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = p0
  []
  [s1]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = s1
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [dictator]
    type = PorousFlowDictator
    porous_flow_vars = 'p0 s1'
    number_fluid_phases = 2
    number_fluid_components = 2
  []
  [pc]
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha
    alpha = alpha
    m = 0.5
    sat_lr = 0.1
    log_extension = false
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [temperature]
    type = PorousFlowTemperature
  []
  [ppss]
    type = PorousFlow2PhasePS
    phase0_porepressure = p0
    phase1_saturation = s1
    capillary_pressure = pc
  []
  [kr0]
    type = PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityVG
    phase = 0
    m = 0.5
  []
  [kr1]
    type = PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityCorey
    phase = 1
    n = 2
  []
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [vpp]
    type = ElementValueSampler
    variable = 's0aux s1aux p0aux p1aux alpha'
    sort_by = id
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
[]

[BCs]
  [sleft]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = s1
    value = 0
    boundary = left
  []
  [sright]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = s1
    value = 1
    boundary = right
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
  execute_on = timestep_end
[]

Hello,
Thank you for the great insight.
I realize that I forgot to set one optional parameter log_extension = false.
  [pc]
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG_alpha
    alpha = alpha
    m = 0.5
    sat_lr = 0.1
    log_extension = false
  []

Which already stated in the document:

Since it's optional parameter so I didn't pay attention to it. Now the simulation can run properly.
Thanks a lot!

node.title: Navier Stokes over multiple blocks
node.bodyText: I was wondering if there was a way to combine temperatures in an auxkernel? I have more than one temperature variable, as a result of using navier stokes, and was wondering if there was a way to combine them into one master variable T so the simulation can be read more easily in paraview. Thanks :)

Hello
You can use two ProjectionAux for that.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/ProjectionAux.html
Create a 3rd auxiliary temperature variable like "temp_out" and use two projectionAux to copy T_fluid and T_solid into it.
This is strictly for output purposes. For using in the nonlinear system, we do not recommend lagging variable values / losing derivative information by using the auxiliary system.
Guillaume
Thank you!!

node.title: ExtraNodesetGenerator with more nodes should be _id node - 1_
node.bodyText:
Hello.
I need to create a selection of nodes (more than 600), so I made this steps:

generate the mesh with gmsh
run the moose script with --mesh-only
open the *_in.e file it in paraview
copy the id nodes from the set of nodes (nodelist_7) by spreadsheet view
made ExtraNodesetGenerator  block into the mesh section
run again the moose script with --mesh-only to obtain the set of nodes

Green light are the nodes that I want and I obtained after realize that the selection of nodes is: id_node -1

I didn't test with less selected nodes (e.g. to include a BC in an injection, the common selection is a single node or a few).
May be it could be specified in the ExtraNodesetGenerator website to avoid future issues.

Hello
I think there's an offset of 1 between the numbering in paraview and the numbering in libmesh. This is a good suggestion though, I ll add a reminder there.
Guillaume

Thanks @GiudGiud
By the way.... is there another option or methodology to do that?
All these steps were done because I need to assign a heat BC in a volume in a PorousFlow problem, so I created this group of nodes inside the volume that I want to....

Hello
As long as these nodes / sides share a common geometrical characteristic, then there are plenty of ways to do this.
One of the most general is to use the ParsedGenerateSideset and specify the equation that these sides satisfy.
If you need the nodes, there is a sideset to nodeset converter in moose
Guillaume

Rotman

node.title: Avoid calculating material properties need only for Jacobian
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
For one nonlinear iteration, the method computeProperties of the material classes is called at least 2 times, once for calculating the residual and once for calculating the Jacobian.
Some properties generated by computeProperties are actually for calculating Jacobian only, for example the pk1_jacobian in solid mechanics. When computeProperties is called for calculating the residual, the calculation for pk1_jacobian is not really needed. For complicate material model, the calculation for pk1_jacobian maybe relatively heavy and slows down the simulation.
So my question is:
Is there a way to know in computeProperies if it is used for calculating the residual or the jacobian, or both (for Executioner/residual_and_jacobian_together=1)? If it is known, user can skip the properties which are used for the Jacobian only when computeProperties is called not for calculation the Jacobian.

Hello
Yes there is a way. You can check the problem with "currentlyComputingJacobian"
_fe_problem.currentlyComputingJacobian()

returns a boolean.
Guillaume
Thanks for the quick answer. I will try it.

node.title: theory/implementation of stress divergence kernel (Jacobian)
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Would anyone be able to provide reference to either an old paper, textbook, or theory manual that best describes the implementation of the finite deformation updated Lagrangian formulation? Specifically, I'm looking to understand the theory and implementation details for the function "StressDivergenceTensors::computeFiniteDeformJacobian()". I would greatly appreciate it if anyone can point me in the right direction. Thanks!
kt

Maybe look for technical reports on OSTI produced by the NEAMS program in mechanics / fuels recently
otherwise @hugary1995 will know

IIRC the old solid mechanics implementation for the "incremental" formulation was following Malvern's textbook "Introduction to the Mechanics of a Continuous Medium". I think some schools still use that textbook, but it's becoming less popular. The StressDivergenceTensors::computeFiniteDeformJacobian() predates me, and I suppose @bwspenc would know the context of that function.
For the new system (i.e. with new_system = true), there is a journal article under review.

node.title: Phase separation in block copolymers
node.bodyText:
Hello team,
I am new to MOOSE and C++. I want to simulate phase separation in block copolymers. For, that I want to change the split formulation to reflect these equations -

Essentially, there is one extra term in the residual of chemical potential.
I have created an auxkernel based modifying SplitCHResBase.h. Here are the new *.h and *.C files I created - SplitCHPhaseSep.zip. Is this the right way to do it? Is there a better way?
When I compile with these files, I get the error -
error: no match for 'operator+=' (operand types are 'libMesh::Real' {aka 'double'} and 'libMesh::boostcopy::enable_if_c<true, libMesh::TypeVector<double> >::type' {aka 'libMesh::TypeVector<double>'})
This error appears in computeQpResidual, computeQpWJacobian and computeQpOffDiagJacobian.
Can anyone help me identify what mistake I might be making?
Thanks in advance,
Raghu.

Hello
error: no match for 'operator+=' (operand types are 'libMesh::Real' {aka 'double'} and 'libMesh::boostcopy::enable_if_c<true, libMesh::TypeVector<double> >::type' {aka 'libMesh::TypeVector<double>'})

means you are summing a vector and a double. You have to use a loop to do that or maybe you do not want this?
  residual += _mob[_qp] * _alpha[_qp] * _kappa[_qp] * (_c[_qp] - _bar_c) * _grad_test[_i][_qp]; //Second term

residual is a real.
The other term is a real times a vector (gradient of the i-th test function at quadrature point qp)
maybe you mean to use _test instead?

Hello @GiudGiud for your reply. What you are saying makes sense, but I am wondering why I am not getting the same error in the first term where I use
Real residual = _mob[_qp] * _grad_w[_qp] * _grad_test[_i][_qp]; //First term
This is also the same expression for computeQpResidual of SplitCHWResBase.h. Hence I believe it should be _grad_test and not just _test. Can you clarify this for me?
Because in that first term you have a grad_w vector term, that causes a dot product with grad_test and you end up with a real.

This makes perfect sense and fixed the errors. Thank you.
But, using this in the input file gives a new error -
Task add_aux_kernel is not registered to build Kernel derived objects
I am unsure if I am using the AuxKernel I developed correctly. Here is the input file (only the relevant parts) -
[Variables]
    # difference in the volume fractions of the 2 phases
    [./u]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
        [./InitialCondition]
            type = RandomIC
            seed = 123
            min = -0.1
            max =  0.1
        [../]
    [../]
    # Chemical potential (J/mol)
    [./w]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
[]
  
[AuxVariables]
    # polymer volume fraction
    [./pvf]
        # order = FIRST
        # family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
[]
  
[Kernels]
    [./w_dot]
        type = CoupledTimeDerivative
        variable = w
        v = u
    [../]
[]
  
[AuxKernels]
    # calculate polymer volume fraction from difference in volume fractions
    [./pvf]
        type = ParsedAux
        variable = pvf
        coupled_variables = 'u'
        expression = '(u+1)/2'
    [../]
    # adding nonlocal term to the energy
    [./coupled_res]
        type = SplitCHPhaseSep
        variable = w
        mob_name = M
        c = u
        alpha_name = alpha
        kappa_name = kappa
    [../]
[]
[Materials]
    # Units of M are m^2 mol / (J s)
    # Units of kappa are J m^2 / mol
    # consider adding a scaling factor in the future
    [./mat]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names  = 'M   kappa    alpha'
        prop_values = '1e-02    5e-03   1e-01'
                        # M*mum_m^2/eV_J
                        # kappa*eV_J*mu_m^2
    [../]
[]

Can you point to what I might be missing or any example problem that deals with a similar thing?

You are adding a kernel in the auxkernel block.
Kernels should go in the [Kernels] block . They are meant to contribute to the residual and Jacobian
Auxkernels are meant to set auxiliary variables.

Thank you @GiudGiud, this worked.
I am trying to calculate the element average value of a variable in my Kernel. What is the best way to do it? I do not need to output it.

Should I use something like QBase::n_points() and do a sum/n_points, or
use ElementAverageValue or ElementIntegralPostprocessor to calculate it

Do you need an average over a single element?
Or an average over the entire mesh?
Are you using automatic differentiation? (AD)

Should I use something like QBase::n_points() and do a sum/n_points, or

This would be for computing the average on each element. There are other options too

use ElementAverageValue or ElementIntegralPostprocessor to calculate it

This would be for computing the average over a larger region of the mesh like a subdomain

If you are not using AD, then you could create an auxiliary variable bar_c of type CONSTANT MONOMIAL.
Then use the ProjectionAux to project c onto bar_c on every linear iterations. This computes bar_c as the average of c on each element

That is an interesting way! Can you tell me how to initialize the _bar_c variable now?
I know I have to use - _bar_c(coupledValue()),, but unsure of what should be the variable name to be used in coupledValue

in the object, add:
params.addCoupledVar("bar_c", ...); 

to the validParams
then you can use
...,
_bar_c(coupledValue("bar_c")),

in the initializer's list of the constructor of your object
